This article covers the '''trials, tribunals, judicial committees and judicial hearings''' that followed the 2011 Egyptian Revolution.
This article covers the '''trials, tribunals, judicial committees and judicial hearings''' that followed the 2011 Egyptian Revolution.
â
The [[2011 Egyptian revolution|2011 Egyptian Revolution]] consisted of the uprising that began on 25 January 2011 which featured a series of demonstrations, marches, acts of civil disobedience, labor strikes, and violent clashes between protestors and security services and supporters of the regime of [[Hosni Mubarak]].<ref>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2011_Egyptian_revolution</ref> The revolution led to the ousting of [[Hosni Mubarak]] from the presedential office. The ousting of Mubarak was followed by a series of arrests of, and / or imposing travel bans on high profile figures on charges of causing the death of 300-500 demonstrators, causing the injury of 5000 demonstrators, as well as charges of [[embezzlement]], [[profiteering]], [[money laundry]] and [[Human rights abuses|abuse of human rights]]. Among these figures are Mubarak himself, his wife [[Suzanne Mubarak]], his son [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]], his son [[Alaa Mubarak|Alaa]], the former interior minister [[Habib el-Adly]], the former housing minister Ahmed El-Maghrabi, the former tourism minister Zoheir Garana and the former secretary of the National Democratic Party for Organisational Affairs [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1036/eg31.htm</ref> Additionally arrest warrants were issued against some public figures who left the country with the eruption of the revolution, on charges of financial misappropriations. Among these public figures are [[Rachid Mohamed Rachid]], the former mminster of trade and industry and Hussein Salem, a business Tycoon. Salem is believed to have left for Dubai<ref>http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000619367&fid=1725</ref> Mubarak's ousted was also followed by widespread allegations of corruption against numerous other government officials and senior politicians,<ref>http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/04/hosni-mubarak-family-fortune</ref><ref>http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289811&IssueID=2068</ref> including the former speaker of the Egyptian Parliament, [[Fathi Sorour]], and the former speaker of the higher legislative body ([[Shura Council]]), [[Safwat El Sherif]].<ref>http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/6644/Egypt/Politics-/NDP-fires-Mubarak--then-what.aspx</ref><ref>http://www.masrawy.com/news/Egypt/Politics/2011/March/6/elshrief_announcement.aspx</ref>
+

===Allegations of human rights abuses===
===Allegations of human rights abuses===
â
On March 5, 2011 and March 6, 2011 numerous Egyptian State Security buildings were stormed by demonstrators after reports that officials were witnessed shredding and burning documents that could serve as evidence against government officials.<ref name="dostor.org">http://dostor.org/politics/egypt/11/march/5/37549</ref> Fires were simultaneously witnessed in a number of Egyptian State Security offices including Cairo downtown office (Lazoghly), 6 October city office, Damanhour, Nasr City, Marsa Matrouh and Alexandria.<ref name="ahram.org.eg">http://www.ahram.org.eg/464/2011/03/07/25/66174.aspx</ref> Large amounts of shredded and burnt documents were found in different state security buildings.<ref name="almasry-alyoum.com">http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289708</ref> The demonstrators reportedly found evidence to support the widely accepted allegation of human rights abuses by Egyptian State Security. The independent newspaper [[Al-Ahram]] reported that Damanhour office of the Egyptian State Security was perhaps the most panic provoking, as prison cells with electrocution equipment were found in close proximity to a secret graveyard.<ref>http://www.ahram.org.eg/464/2011/03/07/25/66081.aspx</ref>
+

==Cases pertaining to public events==
==Cases pertaining to public events==
===The case of public disorder following Jan 28th 2011 ===
===The case of public disorder following Jan 28th 2011 ===
â
Numerous incidents of public disorder occurred from early days of the Egyptian uprising. On January 28, 2011 the police force withdrew from the street of Egypt. A number of prisons were broken into and prisoners were allowed to leave. Some prisons were allegedly opened by prison guards. On February 2, 2011, in what was latterly called the "Battle of the Camel" thugs stormed [[Tahrir square]] in downtown Cairo, where the demonstrators were stationed, and attacked them with Molotov cocktail, rocks, chipped marble, swords and other weapons from horse, donkey and camel backs. This battle resulted in the death of 91 demonstrators and the injury of several hundreds.<ref name="ReferenceA">http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/67082.aspx</ref> A national fact-finding panel was formed to investigate the cause of these incidents of public disorder. This panel was headed by Adel Koura, a judge.<ref name="ReferenceB">http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289996</ref>
+

A number of prisons were broken into and prisoners were allowed to leave. Some prisons were allegedly opened by prison guards. On February 2, 2011, in what was latterly called the "Battle of the Camel" thugs stormed [[Tahrir square]] in downtown Cairo, where the demonstrators were stationed, and attacked them with Molotov cocktail, rocks, chipped marble, swords and other weapons from horse, donkey and camel backs. This battle resulted in the death of 91 demonstrators and the injury of several hundreds.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/67082.aspx |title=Ø·Â­Ø¸ËØ·Â§Ø·Â¯Ø·Â« - Ø¸â Ø¸âØ¸â Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¬Ø·Â§Ø·Â¨Ø·Â±Ø¸Ù¹ Ø¸Ù¾Ø¸Ù¹ Ø·Â­Ø·Â±Ø·Â§Ø·Â³Ø·Â© Ø¸â¦Ø·Â´Ø·Â¯Ø·Â¯Ø·Â© Ø¸âØ¸âØ·Ú¾Ø·Â­Ø¸âØ¸Ù¹Ø¸â Ø¸â¦Ø·Â¹Ø¸â¡ |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> A national fact-finding panel was formed to investigate the cause of these incidents of public disorder. This panel was headed by Adel Koura, a judge.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite web|author=Ø¸â¦Ø·Â­Ø¸â¦Ø·Â¯ Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â³Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Â¯ Ø·ÂµØ·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â­ |url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289996 |title=Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸â¦Ø·ÂµØ·Â±Ø¸â° Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸Ù¹Ø¸ËØ¸â¦ | Ø¢Â«Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸â¦Ø·ÂµØ·Â±Ø¸â° Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸Ù¹Ø¸ËØ¸â¦Ø¢Â» Ø·Ú¾Ø·Â­Ø·ÂµØ¸â Ø·Â¹Ø¸âØ¸â° Ø¸â¦Ø·Â¹Ø¸âØ¸ËØ¸â¦Ø·Â§Ø·Ú¾ Ø¸â¦Ø¸â¡Ø¸â¦Ø·Â© Ø¸â¦Ø¸â  Ø·Ú¾Ø¸âØ·Â±Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Â± Ø¸âØ·Â¬Ø¸â Ø·Â© Ø¢Â«Ø·Ú¾Ø¸âØ·ÂµØ¸â° Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â­Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø·Â¦Ø¸âØ¢Â» Ø·Â­Ø¸ËØ¸â Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø¸â Ø¸Ù¾Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø·Ú¾ Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â£Ø¸â¦Ø¸â Ø¸â° |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
â
The demonstrations of January 28, 2011, and the following days were met by acts of violence. The prosecution reported that upon examining the sites where the demonstrators were shot at empty bullets were found on rooftops of buildings surrounding [[Tahrir Square]], where the demonstrators were stationed. These buildings include the [[American University of Cairo]]. The University was closed at that time, and it is thought that armed officers and thuds had stormer these buildings and shot at the demonstrators. A similar scenario was reported in the area surrounding the Ministry of Interior in [[Cairo]], where demonstrators were shot at from the roof of this ministry. On March 10, 2011, [[Ismail El-Shaer]], the former security cheif of Cairo was interviewed by prosecution regarding these incidents.<ref>http://dostor.org/crime/11/march/10/37850</ref> This was followed by the arrest of Adly Fayed, former Egyptian deputy interior minster for security, Hassan Abdulrahman, chief of state security, Ahmed Ramzy, chief of central security. All four were placed on remand for 15 days starting March 11, 2011.
+

The prosecution reported that upon examining the sites where the demonstrators were shot at empty bullets were found on rooftops of buildings surrounding [[Tahrir Square]], where the demonstrators were stationed. These buildings include the [[American University of Cairo]]. The University was closed at that time, and it is thought that armed officers and thuds had stormer these buildings and shot at the demonstrators. A similar scenario was reported in the area surrounding the Ministry of Interior in [[Cairo]], where demonstrators were shot at from the roof of this ministry. On March 10, 2011, [[Ismail El-Shaer]], the former security cheif of Cairo was interviewed by prosecution regarding these incidents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dostor.org/crime/11/march/10/37850 |title=Ø¥Ø³ÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ´Ø§Ø¹Ø± ÙÙØ«Ù ÙÙØªØ­ÙÙÙ Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø£ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙØ© Ø§ÙØ¹ÙÙØ§ ÙÙ Ø§ØªÙØ§ÙØ§Øª ÙØªÙ Ø§ÙÙØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ±ÙÙ | Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± |publisher=Dostor.org |date=2011-03-10 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> This was followed by the arrest of Adly Fayed, former Egyptian deputy interior minster for security, Hassan Abdulrahman, chief of state security, Ahmed Ramzy, chief of central security. All four were placed on remand for 15 days starting March 11, 2011.
â
Interrogation in this case started on March 12, 2011. [[Al-Ahram|Alahram]] daily newspaper reported that a CD recording of telephone conversations between [[Habib el-Adly]], the former interior minster of Egypt and Ahmed Ramzy, chief of central security, was examined as an evidence. In these conversations, Alahram reported, Ramzy received orders from el-Adly to use live ammunitions. Ramzy denied ordering the use of live ammunitions, but admitted that he ordered the use of rubber bullets and tear gas. Ramzy also stated that el-Adly ordered the withdrawal of the whole police force from the streets the evening of January 28, 2008 only after the military assumed responsibility. Ramzy claimed that this decision was made to avoid further confrontation between the police and the public. This account was supported by the statements of Adly Fayed, former Egyptian deputy interior minster for security, who confirmed that the withdrawal of the police force was to avoid further bloodshed.<ref name="ReferenceC">http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/66964.aspx</ref>
+
Interrogation in this case started on March 12, 2011. [[Al-Ahram|Alahram]] daily newspaper reported that a CD recording of telephone conversations between [[Habib el-Adly]], the former interior minster of Egypt and Ahmed Ramzy, chief of central security, was examined as an evidence. In these conversations, Alahram reported, Ramzy received orders from el-Adly to use live ammunitions. Ramzy denied ordering the use of live ammunitions, but admitted that he ordered the use of rubber bullets and tear gas. Ramzy also stated that el-Adly ordered the withdrawal of the whole police force from the streets the evening of January 28, 2008 only after the military assumed responsibility. Ramzy claimed that this decision was made to avoid further confrontation between the police and the public. This account was supported by the statements of Adly Fayed, former Egyptian deputy interior minster for security, who confirmed that the withdrawal of the police force was to avoid further bloodshed.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/66964.aspx |title=Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â£Ø¸ËØ¸âØ¸â° - Ø·Â­Ø·Â¨Ø·Â³ Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø·Â±Ø·Â¨Ø·Â¹Ø·Â© Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸ÆØ·Â¨Ø·Â§Ø·Â± Ø·Â¨Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¯Ø·Â§Ø·Â®Ø¸âØ¸Ù¹Ø·Â© |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date=2010-09-07 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
[[Ismail El-Shaer]], the former security cheif of Cairo, was also investigated for allegations of ordering the use of weapons against demonstrators and for causing public disorder, which he denied. He was also accused of being the driver in the widely publicized [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NrVI0pCysuU van incident], in which a police van was witnessed plowing into the demonstrators. El-Shaer denied that and stated that he was in his office at the time of this incident.<ref name="ReferenceC"/>
[[Ismail El-Shaer]], the former security cheif of Cairo, was also investigated for allegations of ordering the use of weapons against demonstrators and for causing public disorder, which he denied. He was also accused of being the driver in the widely publicized [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NrVI0pCysuU van incident], in which a police van was witnessed plowing into the demonstrators. El-Shaer denied that and stated that he was in his office at the time of this incident.<ref name="ReferenceC"/>
â
On the day following the arrest and initial interrogation of El-Shaer, Ramzy, Fayed and Abdulrahman, it was announced that the fact-finding panel headed by Judge Adel Koura has submitted 4 reports to the Egyptian prosecutor general.Koura refused to name any officials that may be formally legally charged with causing the death of the protesters, but stated that the police force is not permitted to use live am munitions without an authorization from the interior minster, whose decision must be approved by the country's political leadership.<ref>http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/67070.aspx</ref>
+
On the day following the arrest and initial interrogation of El-Shaer, Ramzy, Fayed and Abdulrahman, it was announced that the fact-finding panel headed by Judge Adel Koura has submitted 4 reports to the Egyptian prosecutor general.Koura refused to name any officials that may be formally legally charged with causing the death of the protesters, but stated that the police force is not permitted to use live am munitions without an authorization from the interior minster, whose decision must be approved by the country's political leadership.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/67070.aspx |title=Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â£Ø¸ËØ¸âØ¸â° - Ø·Â¶Ø·Â¨Ø·Â§Ø·Â· Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â´Ø·Â±Ø·Â·Ø·Â©: Ø·Â§Ø·Â·Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø¸â Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸â Ø·Â§Ø·Â± Ø·Â¹Ø¸âØ¸Ù¹ Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸â¦Ø·Ú¾Ø·Â¸Ø·Â§Ø¸â¡Ø·Â±Ø¸Ù¹Ø¸â  Ø·Â¨Ø¸âØ·Â±Ø·Â§Ø·Â± Ø¸â¦Ø¸â  Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¹Ø·Â§Ø·Â¯Ø¸âØ¸Ù¹ Ø¸ËØ·Â¥Ø·Â·Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø·Â¹ Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸âØ¸Ù¹Ø·Â§Ø·Â¯Ø·Â© Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â³Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Â§Ø·Â³Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Â© |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
The events of February 2, 2011 (see above) also led to allegations that members of the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] coordinated the activities of thugs who stormed [[Tahrir square]] on animal backs and attacked the demonstrators with rocks, swords and Molotov cocktail. The investigations of the fact-finding panel led by Adel Koura confirmed that two MPs from the National Democratic Party were involved in these events, allegedly coordinating the thugs activities and funding them. These two MPs were named in Al-Ahram newspaper: [[Youssef Khatab]] and [[Abdulnasser el-Gabri]], both were arrested on March 10, 2011.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
The events of February 2, 2011 (see above) also led to allegations that members of the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] coordinated the activities of thugs who stormed [[Tahrir square]] on animal backs and attacked the demonstrators with rocks, swords and Molotov cocktail. The investigations of the fact-finding panel led by Adel Koura confirmed that two MPs from the National Democratic Party were involved in these events, allegedly coordinating the thugs activities and funding them. These two MPs were named in Al-Ahram newspaper: [[Youssef Khatab]] and [[Abdulnasser el-Gabri]], both were arrested on March 10, 2011.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
â
On March 21, 2011 the fact finding panel formed to investigate these events submitted its final report to the military council in charge of Egypt (see paragraph 1). [[Al-Ahram|Alahram]] newspaper reported some of the findings from this report including that 685 demonstrators were killed in these events, and approximately 5000 were injured, including 1200 with eye injuries, and many with head injuries indicating that these demonstrators were aimed at with the intention to kill. The report named a number of political figures, business men and police officers as suspects in these events <ref>http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/68627.aspx#comments</ref>.
+
On March 21, 2011 the fact finding panel formed to investigate these events submitted its final report to the military council in charge of Egypt (see paragraph 1). [[Al-Ahram|Alahram]] newspaper reported some of the findings from this report including that 685 demonstrators were killed in these events, and approximately 5000 were injured, including 1200 with eye injuries, and many with head injuries indicating that these demonstrators were aimed at with the intention to kill. The report named a number of political figures, business men and police officers as suspects in these events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/68627.aspx#comments |title=Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â£Ø¸ËØ¸âØ¸â° - 685 Ø·Â´Ø¸â¡Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Â¯Ø·Â§ Ø¸ËØ·Â§Ø¸ÆØ·Â«Ø·Â± Ø¸â¦Ø¸â  5 Ø·Â¢Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø¸Ù¾ Ø¸â¦Ø·ÂµØ·Â§Ø·Â¨ Ø¸Ù¾Ø¸â° Ø·Â£Ø·Â­Ø·Â¯Ø·Â§Ø·Â« Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â«Ø¸ËØ·Â±Ø·Â© .. ===Investigations of sectarian violence===
===Investigations of sectarian violence===

Violence between Christians and Muslims came in the aftermath of burning of a church in the village of Soul; Nr Helwan, south of Cairo. Fighting erupted in the suburbs of Cairo, resulting in at least 11 dead and 140 wounded. Muslims allegedly burned the church because of a relationship between a Coptic man and a Muslim woman.<ref>http://www.thenewamerican.com/index.php/world-mainmenu-26/africa-mainmenu-27/6655-riots-erupt-in-cairo-after-church-is-burned</ref> Media in Egypt claimed that previous members of the National Democratic Party, and elements from the embattled state security service were behind this incident.

==Cases pertaining to individuals==

On 28 February 2011, Egypt's top prosecutor ordered an asset freeze for Mubarak and his family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Egypt-Issues-Travel-Ban-Asset-Freeze-on-Mubarak-117076003.html |title=Egypt Issues Travel Ban, Asset Freeze on Mubarak | News | English |publisher=Voanews.com |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> This was followed by arrest warrants, travel bans and Judicial orders to freeze the assets of other known public figures.
===The Mubaraks' case===
===The Mubaraks' case===
â
On February 28, 2011, Abdel Magid Mahmud, the Prosecutor General of Egypt put a freeze on the assets of ousted president Hosni Mubarak and his family and imposed a travel ban on them.<ref>http://www.ndtv.com/article/world/mubarak-banned-from-leaving-egypt-assets-frozen-88439</ref> Subsequently the Egyptian government asked the U.S. and the European Union to freeze the assets of the Mubaraks, while an investigation is carried out into the widespread allegations of profiteering against Mubarak, his wife Suzanne, his son Alaa and his son Gamal.<ref>http://www.aljazeerah.info/News/2011/February/21%20n/Egyptian%20Government%20Wants%20Mubarak%20Family's%20Foreign%20Assets%20Frozen.htm</ref> The Mubarak family sought legal representation for this case and on March 6, 2011, it was reported that Mohamad Hamouda, Hosni Mubarak's previous lawyer will represent him. Hamouda stated that he agreed to represent Mubarak on certain conditions, including that Mubarak family inform him of their exact assets. Hamouda also stated that Mubarak will take a legal action against the British Newspaper the Guardian and the American Newspaper New York Times for defamation.<ref>http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21530&catid=150&Itemid=69</ref> On the following day Hamouda declared that he will not represent Mubarak citing his "discomfort" with the case as the reason for withdrawing. Hamouda stated that acheiving justice in this case will be difficult. He explained that he was given only three days to review evidentiary documents and two days into this period he had not yet received these documents from the prosecutor. Hamouda stated that another lawyer, Mourtada Mansour, accepted to represent the Mubaraks. Cairo criminal court was scheduled to start proceedings in this case on March 8, 2011,<ref>http://www.elbashayer.com/news-130937.html</ref> however, on that day neither Mubarak, no his council appeared in court.<ref>http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/march/8/mobarak_money.aspx</ref> The court ordered that Mubarak and his family remain on travel ban. The court also upheld the decision made by the prosecutor to freeze Mubaraks' account, citing that there is sufficient evidence to suspect that Mubarak and his family profiteered and misappropriated public funds.<ref>http://www.ahram.org.eg/465/2011/03/08/27/66267.aspx</ref> Mubaraks' case was assigned to two Egyptian court: the appeal court, to consider the travel ban imposed upon the Mubarak family, and the criminal court to consider the financial charges.<ref>http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289932&IssueID=2069</ref>
+

===Rachid Mohamed Rachid's case===
===Rachid Mohamed Rachid's case===
â
[[Rachid Mohamed Rachid]] became Egypt's Minister of Foreign Trade and Industry in July 2004. On the 28th February 2011 [[Hosni Mubarak|Mubarak]] dissolved his then cabinet to form the last cabinet before his ousted. It was reported that Racheed, who was in Dubai at the time of the revolution, was offered a ministerial position in Mubarak's last cabinet, but he refused. Racheed became the first high profile figure to be accused of financial irregularities; he was charged while Mubarak was still in office. The timing of the allegations of financial irregularities against Rachid raised some doubts as to whether these allegations were actually disseminated in response to Rachid's refusal to accept an office in Mubarak's last government, or to be scapegoated as the public call for an end to corruption was becomming louder.<ref>http://www.just-international.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4190:egypt-25-january-revolution-whats-next&catid=45:recent-articles&Itemid=123</ref>
+

===Habib el-Adly's case===
===Habib el-Adly's case===
â
The trial of Habib el-Adly follows two streams of legal charges: the first pertains to profiteering activities, and the second pertains to allegations that el-Adly ordered the use of live ammunitions against the demonstrators during January 2011 protests in different Egyptian cities, and was responsible for the opening of different jails in Egypt during these protests in order to cause criminal unrest and justify the use of force during these protests.<ref>http://www.ahram.org.eg/463/2011/03/06/25/65906.aspx</ref> A fact finding panel was formed to assess the responsibility for incidents of criminal unrest. On March 9, 2011 the Egyptian daily newspaper Almasry Alyoum reported that el-Adly's charges in this case may be of political rather than criminal nature as there is an evidence available to the fact finding mission that he might have acted on orders from the countries president rather than at his own accord.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
+

On March 9, 2011 the Egyptian daily newspaper Almasry Alyoum reported that el-Adly's charges in this case may be of political rather than criminal nature as there is an evidence available to the fact finding mission that he might have acted on orders from the countries president rather than at his own accord.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
â
El-Adly appeared before Gize Criminal Court on March 5, 2011 where he was formally charged with profiteering and money laundry. These charges relate to allegations that el-Adly received a bribe of 4.5 million Egyptian pounds to allow a contractor to carry out some building work on behalf of the Egyptian ministry of interior. El-Adly pleaded not guilty, and the court proceedings were adjourned to April 2, 2011 to allow el-Adly's council to review the evidence. This trial was described by the Egyptian daily, [[Al-Ahram|Alahram]], as the Egyptian trial of the century.<ref>http://www.ahram.org.eg/463/2011/03/06/25/65906.aspx</ref> El-Adly's police department was widely feared by the Egyptians, and the allegations that he caused the widespread thuggery during and after the Egyptian protests of January 25/2011 to February 12/2011, by opening jails, led to large demonstrations infornt of the Giza Courthouse calling for el-Adly's execution.<ref>http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/69C7960A-D11A-4E24-B1DF-E9E155609F0E.htm?GoogleStatID=20</ref>

=== Zoheir Garana's case===
=== Zoheir Garana's case===
On March 6, 2011 the Egyptian daily newspaper alwafd reported that the [[Prosecutor General]] of Egypt has referred Zoheir Garana, the tourism minster under [[Hosni Mubarak]], to Cairo criminal court on suspicions of [[embezzlement]] and [[profiteering]]. Garana was accused of misusing public funds amounting to 51 million [[Egyptian pound]]s. It is noteworthy that Garana was arrested and placed on [[remand]] more than a week before the court referral order was issued by the Prosecutor General.<ref>http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21341:Ø¥Ø­Ø§ÙØ©-Ø¬Ø±Ø§ÙØ©-ÙØ§ÙØ­Ø§Ø°Ù-ÙØ³Ø¬ÙØ§ÙÙ-ÙÙØ¬ÙØ§ÙØ§Øª&catid=150:Ø«ÙØ±Ø©%20Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨&Itemid=409</ref>
On March 6, 2011 the Egyptian daily newspaper alwafd reported that the [[Prosecutor General]] of Egypt has referred Zoheir Garana, the tourism minster under [[Hosni Mubarak]], to Cairo criminal court on suspicions of [[embezzlement]] and [[profiteering]]. Garana was accused of misusing public funds amounting to 51 million [[Egyptian pound]]s. It is noteworthy that Garana was arrested and placed on [[remand]] more than a week before the court referral order was issued by the Prosecutor General.<ref>http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21341:Ø¥Ø­Ø§ÙØ©-Ø¬Ø±Ø§ÙØ©-ÙØ§ÙØ­Ø§Ø°Ù-ÙØ³Ø¬ÙØ§ÙÙ-ÙÙØ¬ÙØ§ÙØ§Øª&catid=150:Ø«ÙØ±Ø©%20Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨&Itemid=409</ref>
â
Garana has not formally been put on trial, yet was detained in Tora Prison on mere suspicions (see sections below: concerns about scapegoating of officials, concerns about differential/ preferential justice). As with many of those charged in the aftermath of the Egyptian revolution, Garana's decisions/actions were seen as compliant with the policies set by the government in which he served "{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}}. The 51 million Mr. Garana is accused of misusing, refers to the sale of a 5 million square meter piece of land in Ein El Sokhna. Mr. Garana sealed the deal in accordance to a presidential decree made on July 4, 2005 where the price is $1 per meter "{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}}.. It is claimed that Garana alloted pieces of land, al a low price, to a a company named "Royal", which he owns <ref>http://dostor.org/crime/11/march/21/38583</ref>.

===Concerns that the judiciary may enter in legal deals with some of the accused===
===Concerns that the judiciary may enter in legal deals with some of the accused===
â
On March 21, 2011, Alwafd daily newspaper reported that the possibility of a legal deal between the prosecution and some of those accused of embezzlement was explored. Alwafd stated that this option was explored after prosecution was successful in striking a deal with some creditors and business burrowers to repay a total of 13 billion Egyptian pounds in return for dropping legal charges. The situation with those listed above, according to Alwafd, proved more complex as the offers made by the accused, in return for dropping the embezzlement charges, were seen as unrealistic <ref>http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=25966:Ø§ÙÙØ²Ø±Ø§Ø¡-Ø¹Ø±Ø¶ÙØ§-Ø±Ø¯-ÙØ§ÙÙØ¨ÙÙ-ÙØ§ÙÙÙØ§Ø¨Ø©-Ø±ÙØ¶Øª&catid=98:ÙØ­ÙÙØ©&Itemid=92</ref>.

===Prioritizing charges of embezzlement over charges of human rights abuses===
===Prioritizing charges of embezzlement over charges of human rights abuses===
â
The first wave of legal actions that started following Mubarak's resignation was dominated by charges of financial nature, including bribery, misappropriation of funds, profiteering, [[embezzlement]] and money laundry. This caused concerns to some, particularly in the case of [[Habib el-Adly]], former interior minster, whose public figure was much more eroded by allegations of human rights abuses, yet only faced legal charges over financial matters during the first wave of legal action. On March 16, 2011 the families of some of protestors killed by the police forces demonstrated in front of the office of the general prosecutor of egypt, for what they saw as exclusive focus on financial cases at the expense of human rights cases. Some of these families claimed that the legal files pertaining to their killed relatives were not yet received by the prosecution as on March 16, 2011 <ref>90 Minutes, Al-Mehwar TV, March 17, 2011</ref>.

Some of these families claimed that the legal files pertaining to their killed relatives were not yet received by the prosecution as on March 16, 2011.<ref>90 Minutes, Al-Mehwar TV, March 17, 2011</ref>

=== Allegations of concealment and disposal of evidentiary documents pertaining to the trials===
=== Allegations of concealment and disposal of evidentiary documents pertaining to the trials===
â
On March 5, 2011 and March 6, 2011 numerous Egyptian State Security buildings were stormed by demonstrators after reports that officials were witnessed shredding and burning documents that could serve as evidence against government officials.<ref name="dostor.org"/> Fires were simultaneously witnessed in a number of Egyptian State Security offices including Cairo downtown office (Lazoghly), 6 October city office, Damanhour, Nasr City, Marsa Matrouh and Alexandria.<ref name="ahram.org.eg"/> These fires were witnessed the day after the government of [[Ahmed Shafik]], that last of Mubarak's prime minsters, had resigned. Large amounts of shredded and burnt documents were found in different state security buildings.<ref name="almasry-alyoum.com"/> The demonstrators reportedly found some documenta CDs, video and audiotape recordings pertaining to a number of recent events in Egypt including the explosion in the Two Saints Church in Alexandria on December 31, 2010, in which the state security apparatus, under [[Habib el-Adli|Habib El-Adli]], was allegedly involved. Documents pertaining to spying, blackmailing and torture activities were also found and handed over to the state prosecutor.<ref>http://www.ahram.org.eg/463/2011/03/06/38/65967.aspx</ref>
+

On March 6, 2011 It was reported that among the documents that were found in a readable condition in the Egyptian State Security buildings was a file from the office of Hassan Abdulrahman, the former deputy interior minster under Mubarak, with instructions to various branches of Egyptian State Security buildings to shred archived documents. These documents are believed to contain relevant information to the widespread allegations of human rights abuses by the Egyptian State Security.<ref>http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21420:ÙÙÙ-ÙØ¤Ø§ÙØ±Ø©-Ø£ÙÙ-Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙØ©&catid=144:ÙÙÙØ§Øª%20ÙØ­ÙÙØ©&Itemid=337</ref> In an interview with [[BBC]] Arabic TV on March 7, 2011, General F Allam, previous deputy director of the Egyptian State Security stated that the burning of these documents will not impact the evidence required for any court case, as copies of all these documents are automatically archived in confidential locations. General Allam argued that indeed an order might have been issued to shred or burn these documents due to fears that these documents may fall "in the wrong hands" if state security buildings are stormed by demonstrators.<ref>BBC Arabic: Interview with Sakina Fouad, General F Allam, and Mr Wael, a representative of the demonstrators, March 7, 2011</ref>
